title: 1584-G
statement: G. Eligible Segmentstime limit per test3 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputYou are given $$$n$$$distinctpoints $$$p_1, p_2, \\ldots, p_n$$$ on the plane and a positive integer $$$R$$$.Find the number of pairs of indices $$$(i, j)$$$ such that $$$1 \\le i < j \\le n$$$, and for every possible $$$k$$$ ($$$1 \\le k \\le n$$$) the distance from the point $$$p_k$$$ to thesegmentbetween points $$$p_i$$$ and $$$p_j$$$ is at most $$$R$$$.InputThe first line contains two integers $$$n$$$, $$$R$$$ ($$$1 \\le n \\le 3000$$$, $$$1 \\le R \\le 10^5$$$) — the number of points and the maximum distance between a point and a segment.Each of the next $$$n$$$ lines contains two integers $$$x_i$$$, $$$y_i$$$ ($$$-10^5 \\le x_i, y_i \\le 10^5$$$) that define the $$$i$$$-th point $$$p_i=(x_i, y_i)$$$. All points are distinct.It is guaranteed that the answer does not change if the parameter $$$R$$$ is changed by at most $$$10^{-2}$$$.OutputPrint the number of suitable pairs $$$(i, j)$$$.ExamplesInput4 2 0 1 0 -1 3 0 -3 0Output1Input3 3 1 -1 -1 -1 0 1Output3NoteIn the first example, the only pair of points $$$(-3, 0)$$$, $$$(3, 0)$$$ is suitable. The distance to the segment between these points from the points $$$(0, 1)$$$ and $$$(0, -1)$$$ is equal to $$$1$$$, which is less than $$$R=2$$$.In the second example, all possible pairs of points are eligible.

processed.result: You are given a set of points on a plane and a distance limit.  Find the number of pairs of points where every other point is within the distance limit of the line segment connecting the pair.

You are given $n$ distinct points on a plane,  $p_1, p_2, ..., p_n$.  Find the number of pairs of indices $(i, j)$ where $1 \le i < j \le n$, and for every point $p_k$ (where $1 \le k \le n$), the distance from $p_k$ to the line segment between $p_i$ and $p_j$ is at most $R$.

Input:

* The first line contains two integers $n$ and $R$ ($1 \le n \le 3000$, $1 \le R \le 10^5$) — the number of points and the maximum allowed distance.
* Each of the next $n$ lines contains two integers $x_i$ and $y_i$ ($-10^5 \le x_i, y_i \le 10^5$) that define the $i$-th point $p_i = (x_i, y_i)$.

Output:

Print the number of suitable pairs $(i, j)$.
